I‚Äôve read John several times but today, I found it curious that Jesus used the stone jars used for the ‚ÄúJewish Ritual of Purification‚Äù for the miracle of turning water to wine.  

This ritual of purification is central to Jewish tradition.  The ‚ÄúLaw‚Äù / ‚ÄúTorah‚Äù (of the Old Testament), commanded cleansing with water for physical and spiritual purification.  We all know that cleanliness is both a prerequisite of holiness and an aid to physical fitness / hygiene.  

But why did Jesus use these ceremonial stone jars?

He asked them to fill the jars with ‚Äúwater‚Äù (John 6:7).  

Two things came to my mind here:

1.) Water refreshes dryness and water brings life.  Water was (and still is) recognized for natural cleansing.  To the Jews at that time, water coming from their ceremonial cleansing jars had to be for their cleansing ritual - which occurred on the outside.  By turning the ‚Äúwater‚Äù from the ceremonial cleansing jars into ‚Äúwine‚Äù (which is a symbol for the Holy Spirit according to Ephesians 5:18), Jesus was trying to show them (and show us) a new way.  Jesus changes the water - which washes the outer body, into the wine of the Spirit - which cleanses and regenerates internally. Jesus uses this miracle to teach us that the work of ceremonial cleansing with water could only go so far, and at best remain superficial.  But the work of cleansing by the wine of the Holy Spirit launches us to a new way of life.  Remember, John the Baptist said he baptized with water (ceremonial / traditional cleansing) but Jesus was going to baptize with the Holy Spirit (new wine) and fire.  


2.) This work of the Holy Spirit is symbolized literally to us, as new wine coming into old earthen vessels.  

This led to a bunch of questions for me:

a.) If the new wine symbolizes the (work of) Holy Spirit, then it cannot stay closed in a vessel.  Despite how significant (ceremonial) or pretty the vessel is, the new wine is useless if it is not poured out to others.  The new wine in my life must be shared to fill a void / need in the lives of everyone I encounter.  The work of the Holy Spirit must me manifest in my life. 

b.) If there is new wine, then new wine skins are needed.  The former way of doing things must change.  What am I doing on my part to ensure that this new wine does not remain in an old vessel? What steps am I taking to transition to the new level of holiness, prayerfulness, worship, service, giving? What new approaches to my faith walk, personal life, career, relationships does God want me to embrace in 2021 and beyond?

I really enjoyed chapter 1. I found it very ingesting that at every point John reminded the people that he is not the Messiah he is just here to make the path. I think this tells us to work in God‚Äôs purpose for our lives and to do it well.

John 2:7 was what stood out to me when I was reading my bible, When Jesus told the servants to fill the water jars during the wedding at Cana, Galilee he did not tell them where to fill them up to, but the servants filled them up to the brim even though they could have filled them halfway. It means that we determine how much we want God to bless us, whether it is halfway or fully to the brim.

John 1:4 It is the Word that give life to everyone and everything and make them function the way they function. So no one can really boast in their capacity or of what they can do because if the Word withdraws it's ability, the thing or the person is disabled.

John 2:5 It is in the doing of the Word that the miraculous is released.

Like the story of creation, we see that Jesus‚Äô first miracle is at a wedding of a man and his wife (a celebration). He was there when things were good, and his presence when things were bad led to an outcome even better than their original good (i.e. best wine at the end). Today, I learnt that His presence can turn my ordinary water into extraordinary wine! His presence doesn‚Äôt hinder our celebration, but keeps the party going and memorable.

John 1:10-11, 20-21, 31-34, 46-50
Sometimes in expecting blessings to come in a certain way, we miss what God actually has for us. The Jewish leaders expected a Messiah, but were so bound by their image of who he should be that they did not recognize Him. John the Baptist initially did not until he saw the Holy Spirit rest upon Jesus, and neither did Nathaniel until he spent some time with Jesus. Like John and Nathaniel we should be open to God's guidance and spend time with Him when we doubt or are unsure.
Expect the miraculous to happen, but don't set your mind on how. Let God do his thing.

Meaning as Christian's we can stand in the gap for others, to see God manifest himself in their lives, even  without letting them know at first.

In vs. 29 of John 3, 
> Quoted Text

The bride belongs to the bridegroom. The friend who attends the bridegroom waits and listens for him, and is full of joy when he hears the bridegroom‚Äôs voice. That joy is mine, and it is now complete.

This is how our growth in faith should be - should be like a nosedive into the fullness of God. No delay. The long wait for the Messiah had finally manifested, and the lucky few in the beginning, grasped unto it. It covers all we should experience as born-again Christians, from conversion/baptism/acceptance, and knowing how we should be about our Father's business.

My reflection is on, how easy it took people to believe christ with the little they see or experienced! John 1:50 stood out for me. " I will see greater things than these"......

All around us is the beauty of God's creation; the world was empty but God filled it with beauty and light! God can always be relied on to make something out of nothing....beauty out of ashes. The basis of God's actions is the WORD, which was first and represents GOD Himself. If I can trust God's word, that means I trust God. Like John....we should never think of ourselves as being too great, we must "decrease so God can increase" in our lives, empty ourselves and trust that God will fill us with His beauty and light!

Witnessing is a key part of God's approach to introducing the light to the world. 

Note that God could have sent Jesus Christ to the world without John to perform all miracles, but He sent John (a witness) first. 

This implies that witnessing is a big part of God's plan and a major expectation from us, to ensure the light continues to spread all through the world.

"And he said to him, ‚ÄúEvery man at the beginning sets out the good wine, and when the guests have well drunk, then the inferior. You have kept the good wine until now!‚Äù John 2:10

It is in the nature of man to hoard and withhold. To peddle a counterfeit while keeping the best for ourselves and those we favour, only parting with it by charging a very high price or in the expectation of the plaudits of men.  Not so with Christ. The couple did not even know that they were starting at shame but without any fanfare He performed a miracle of provision of such high quality that the expert had to acknowledged it. But this is Jesus on any given day. He is at His best all the time. His gift of salvation is incorruptible, His love for us is eternal, His thoughts towards us are good all the time, He supplies according to His riches in glory and He does exceedingly abundantly above our highest expectations! Everything about Him and His interaction with us is superlative. He is certainly worth believing, pursuing and serving all our days!
